   Hello everyone, new member here. My name is Mike and I was 
recently off=
ered a couple japanese swords. I have been collecting 
swords for the past =
10 years or so, but primarily European. The one 
is a WWII officer's with a=
 mei on the blade of Ando Kanemoto. It is 
in beautiful shape and I did not=
 see any faults with it at all. 
   The other one has me a bit confused whi=
ch is one reason I joined 
the group. The blade is unsigned, but the tsuba =
does have a 
signature. I have asked a lot of people, but no one is able to=
 give 
me a definate answer as to what it is. I assume the 2 sets of 
chara=
cters is that of the smith and the school, but I don't know for 
sure. Pict=
ures of the tsuba and the tsuka can be found in the folder 
I created at:

=
http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/9ea7?c=3D

Like=
 I hinted at, I am quite new to Japanese weaponry, and 
translating kanji i=
s certainly wayyyy out of my field. What I have 
been able to come up with =
on the tsuba could be a few things. First, 
the 2 charcters on the left (I =
don't know if everyone has the kanji 
font on their computers but I will pu=
t it here anyways).

I see =89p for sure which I believe is either "teru" o=
r "hide" the 2nd 
character I have not determined for sure.

On the right s=
ide, I see either =97=B3 (tatsu) or possibly `=EA (taki) 
followed by, I be=
lieve =8F=E4 (don't know the pronounciation) and then =8Eq 
(shi).

Obvious=
ly, what I want to know is who this tsuba is made by and the 
school it is =
from. But also a potential date. I was informed by the 
owner of the sword =
that it was authenticated by a friend of mine and 
he thought it to be from=
 the late 1600s or 1700s, but that is 
certainly unclear.

Thank you all in=
 advance for your help. 

Mike
